name: San Marzano Tomato
climate: Prefers a warm climate with temperatures between 70-85Â°F for optimal growth.
Cannot withstand frost; thrives in USDA hardiness zones 10-11.
Needs a long growing season, ideally free from sudden temperature drops.
High humidity is beneficial, but good air circulation is also essential to prevent diseases.
sunlight: Requires full sunlight, at least 6-8 hours of direct sun daily for best fruiting.
Insufficient sunlight might lead to leggy plants and reduced yields.
The plants do best in a location where they can receive unobstructed sunlight throughout the day.
Avoid shaded areas as inadequate sun can stunt growth and affect fruit quality.
watering: Needs regular watering, with soil kept consistently moist but not waterlogged.
Deep watering once or twice a week is ideal, avoiding daily surface watering.
During hot and dry periods, increase watering frequency to maintain soil moisture.
Mulching can help retain soil moisture and stabilize temperature around the roots.
soil: Prefers rich, well-draining soil with lots of organic matter for proper nutrient supply.
Soil pH should ideally range from 6.0 to 6.8 for optimal nutrient uptake and growth.
Good drainage is crucial to prevent root rot and other water-related diseases.
Regular soil amendment with compost or well-rotted manure is recommended for fertility.
extra_care_tip: Pruning the lower leaves can improve air circulation and reduce disease risk.
Staking or caging the plants is important to support the heavy fruit load and prevent breakage.
Regularly monitor for pests like aphids and caterpillars; use organic sprays if needed.
Rotate crops annually to prevent soil-borne diseases and improve soil health.
